And let not the blood clot be permitted to collect at all within it: for when a blood clot collects upon the membrane of the brain it corrupts it and putrifies it and happens upon the sick man after that great wickedness; and now it happens in the head when the mouth is cleansed from that, especially when the cure of it is neglected, blackness on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	And consider therefore when these accidents which we have said happen to the sick man know that it is by far wickedness.Et omnia quae sunt praeterita, fac ut sint secundum regulam et rationem, quoniam multum est in his, et non potest scribi singula cum singulis: sed sic describere sufficit ut per omnes partes.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And all which are past let be according to rule and reason, for there is much in these and it cannot be written severally with each; but thus to describe suffices for every part. And if blackness does not happen except by the medicine which is put upon it and is in the strength of that medicine to make that blackness: then it behooves that you take a part from honey, three parts from rosated oil, and linen with these.And ponas super eum, et faciatur ad punctum, et tenetur, donec sit ut sit quasi in macula nigra, et postea solvatur cum aqua calida et sanguine.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then place him over a chamber pot; afterwards care for him with such remedies as are suitable until he recovers.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	Then you will restore the nose when it is broken.
Caput IIII.	CHAPTER IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Know that only two parts of the nose can break at once, or one of them: because it has two bones; for its lower part is cartilage and does not break, and nothing happens to it except attrition, and tortuosity, and simili.¶ Si autem superior pars frangerit, et os non vertet in contrariam partem, sed frustra vertatur, quod est contra naturam: aut si vertatur ad contrariam partem, et ossa contra se iungantur, neque possunt ad inveteratem positionem revocari, sed debet excisus esse.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If the upper part breaks, and the bone does not turn into the opposite part, but turns uselessly, which is contrary to nature; or if it turns into the opposite part, and the bones join together against each other, they cannot be recalled to their old position, but it must be cut off. If one of its two parts breaks, then you must put your little finger into the nostril hole, and equally that broken part with your index finger and thumb, until the nose returns above its natural shape; and let this be done skillfully, with ease.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And beware lest it happen through your operation to that weak pain. And if it has turned towards the opposite part, and the bones have joined together, so that they cannot be recalled to their old position, then cut off a piece from its end which is in the direction of the turn, and split open its head; let this happen on both sides, then it will return into its natural shape.And if you find in it a white blood clot which blocks it, take out all of that; for it is what causes it to be tortuous.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	If the break is in the upper part of the nose, and it does not reach it with the finger, then it must be equalized at the end of the bone, in which there is a small thickness. Et si peruenit digitus ad illam partem: oportet, ut trahatur ultra naturam suam, donec audias sonum fracturas ossium: et postea redde illum ad naturam suam, sed non ultra.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	And if the finger reaches that part, then it must be pulled beyond its nature, until you hear the sound of the broken bones; and then return it to its nature, but not beyond. But if the break is in two parts, do the like of it: and hasten with its restoration on the first day of the break, if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day by the calm of the hot pustule. Nam antea non debes intrare ad operationem, nisi post diem quintum: quoniam praecipiens est ad te, ut facias eam in die primo.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then insert into the extremity of the nose a piece of linen as large as an egg, if the fracture is in one place; or insert two pieces of linen, if it is in two places; and let there be in the linen enough thickness to fill the hole of the nose.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some ancient surgeons have said that the pieces of linen should be soaked in butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	But this does not seem right to me, rather it ought to be that the piece of linen is soaked in egg white beaten with flour.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then leave the piece of linen until the bone is set and the cartilage hardened.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the nose instead of a piece of linen, after it has been wrapped in a soft cloth; and it holds the fracture of the nose more firmly and so the invalid is not prevented from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish do that; and if you wish do the other.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	If a pustule becomes hot on the nose while you are operating, apply to it a plaster with poultice, or with cotton wool soaked in rose oil, or with a little diachylon.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	But if no pustule becomes hot then it is right to apply a plaster with sesame meal and powder of the stone called achates, mixed with egg white.Et postea, si uis, fac illum locum licinio uterque subliminare, donec firmet os: et quod uelut illaesit, et percutiat: et si non posset percutere, tantummodo illaesit.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Then afterwards apply a soft bandage to that place and do not bind the nose with anything at all.And if he should sneeze, let him sneeze, or only let him breathe hard there.And then put on a light bandage over it, and not ligature the nose with anything at all.Et non intromittas illum in Nasum licinium, donec percutiat: sed si uis, fac, ut intromittatur: et tunc illaesit.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	If however, bones of the nose are broken with a slight fracture or crushed, then one must split them and draw them out with appropriate instruments.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then close up the cut and heal it with a plaster or ointment suitable for that purpose.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	If this happens to the nose, you must heal it with linen and apply a lead tube until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	Restoration of the lower jaw when broken:
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jaw is broken and there is no wound involved; if you see that it is only broken on the exterior and not split into two, and the fracture does not involve the interior, then it is easy to treat.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	So, if there is a fracture on the right side, then put your left index finger into the mouth of the patient; likewise if the break is in the left jaw, put in the index finger of your right hand: and push with that the bump formed by the fracture directly against the outside from the center with your other hand, using your other hand as a counter-pressure.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	But if the lower jaw is already split into two, then you must apply an extension from both sides according to the straightness until it can be brought back together.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	But if there has already been a dislocation or disruption of the teeth; then tie those from which you hope that they will remain with a thread of gold or silver, or silk.Deinde quando resuperiunt eorum, qui commoti sunt: de quibus sperabas ut remanserunt cum filo: oportet, ut disseceres inter dentem et filum.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then put over the broken jaw a plaster cast.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then put on top of it another double layer of bandage and over the bandage a large and properly made metal splint, or a piece of sole leather equal to the length of the jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then tie it tightly from above according to the method of preparing the ligature, and according to its suitable application until it is healed; and order the patient to maintain stillness and tranquility; and give him soft drinks for food.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If you find that there is some change of shape in any way, then hasten to remove it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then correct what is changed in it by means of a poultice made from flour or with white egg-white, or with sesame meal after you have removed the splinters; and put over the poultice soft wool.Et postea ponito super mandibulam, et super placulum emarginato, et conglutinato cum ligamine.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	And after you have applied the poultice over the jaw and the bandage cut in an indentation, and glued it with a ligature; and as long as the poultice remains attached to it and the arrangement of the bone does not change, leave it, so that it may heal by itself; or string the fracture together.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	This fracture is often bound up for three weeks.Et si post tres hebdomadas non est curata, et tamen est firma et statuta: tunc remove superius ligaturam, sed subplicato placulo: et remeave infra placulum.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	And if after three weeks it has not healed yet, and is still firm and stable; then remove the upper ligature but apply a double bandage; and remove what is under the bandage. If meanwhile a hot pustule appears, then treat it as we have already mentioned many times for its sedative effect, until this pustule is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if the fracture has been accompanied by a wound, consider:Si enim iuxta haec fracturam est uulnus, et multum sanguinis profluxerit per eam: si scis quod non potest curari, nisi post remotionem haec facias: remove postea ligaturam.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	If indeed there is a wound next to this fracture and much blood has flowed through it; if you know that it cannot be healed unless after its removal you do this: then later remove the ligature. But if a piece of bone has separated, or from the gum; then act carefully in this matter so as to pull out those pieces of gum along with whatever is suitable for you in their extraction by means of instruments.Et si scis quod non potest curari nisi remotus sit ille ex osse: et non potest remoti nisi ut separes osse, et ligeres eum ad conuenientem statum, ne disiungatur et dislocetur: remove postea ligaturam.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If the opening of the wound is narrow, then enlarge it with a probe according to your need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have taken out these sutures, and nothing remains of them, then open the opening of the wound, if it is large; and if not, place over it one of the poultices that suit it, and let it heal.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	On the restoration of a broken Collar-bone.
Caput VI.	CHAPTER VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	The collar-bone is most frequently broken from the front part of the shoulder-blade, and the fracture is one of three kinds.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or it is broken, but not separated into two; which is what happens most often, and is the easiest to cure. aut cum separatur in duos, nec tamen disjectus sit in duo: et haec restauratio necesse est sit facienda per ligaturas, ut inferius describitur.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or this: when they occur in the bone of a joint; these are more difficult to restore.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or this: when there is a fracture with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And the operation on it when there is a fracture without a wound is to have two assistants present: one holds the broken furcula in place while the other extends the collar towards the affected part.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then adjust the fracture with your fingers until it is in the proper position and there are no bumps or hollows.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If you need more extension, then place a ball of cloth or wool under the patient's chin, the size according to your needs; and extend and lift the furcula, and hold the ball with your hand until the fracture is properly aligned.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you cannot pull the end of the furcula outward due to its depth, then the patient should lean back over his neck; and place a small pillow under his shoulder, the size depending on your needs, and one assistant presses the shoulder down while another lifts the furcula from below until the broken bone is lifted up. Then straighten the fracture and adjust it with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If you feel a splinter in the furcula and it moves, then you must locate it and remove it with ease.Si autem sentis illum ad interiora moueri: tunc oportet, ut findas sathanataum et extrahas eam in contraria parte.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If it is retained in the bone, then the tools that you have prepared for this purpose must be used to cut it with one of the cutting instruments, after you have placed under the furcula a tool that keeps the wound open. This tool is made from wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It resembles a funnel with no凹(convex) 凹(concave).
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	And its width should be according to what you need from it based on the size of the bone, and its thickness.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	Its length should also depend on what is possible for you during the procedure.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And it has two ends, as you can see: and one end is wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If, however, the wound made when you extracted the splinter from the bone is large and the edges are not even, then bring together the two lips of the wound with a suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if it is small, or the wound is not clean: then fill the wound with bandages and dressings according to the size of the cut wound.Et si os est ruptum: tunc neque sutura, nec pannis, sed cum fascibus ligatura facias.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	If a hot boil occurs, then soak a cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and place it over the boil.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	When a bone fracture occurs without a wound or without any cutting, then an ointment made from flour of bran with egg white should be placed over the bone.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And place a soft poultice over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a ball under the tickle of his nose, if necessary.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take a piece of red iron, that is, a round ball which the Saracens hold, and it should be very long; its breadth should be about the size of a palm, or thereabouts.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a folded napkin over the poultice and ointment.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take a small stick made of thin wood, whose breadth is three fingers wide, and similarly in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it in a napkin.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then wrap that napkin with the stick at the spot which hangs over the fracture and the spot.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the alhimeni over the fracture as it is rolled up, and wrap it around his neck, and under his healthy nostril, and under his sick nostril; and draw it over every part, and in what way you see that the fracture holds the fracture firmly: and it is that which does not conceal itself from you, and altogether, so that the stick does not move from above the fractured bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And for this reason, you must look at the invalid every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Whenever therefore the ligament softens, and you see the stick has moved back, then straighten it, and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place sleep for the invalid on his back, and place under his nostril near sleep with him a small poultice at night, so that it may warm up help from his side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Let the broken collarbone be warmed by the warming of the shoulder.Quamuis enim non sit iuxta se, sed inter posita est aliter: et si non eleuetur per eleuationem humeri, cum eleuat per eleuationem titillici.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Or tie his arm to his neck; and do not loosen the ligature unless an accident occurs as a result of itching, or from a blister, for up to twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then renew the plaster, if you see that it has been damaged.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And add to the tightness and leave it until it is restored and coagulated.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	And indeed, a fracture of the collarbone is bound and supported as much as possible within nineteen days; and sometimes it happens in some men in that less time.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	Of the restoration of a fracture of the spatula.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	It is rare for the spatula to break except at its edges. And they are not broken unless by accident, or from an aposteme, for up to twelve days.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	When therefore the place is broken and broken in its middle, and it is not known except by touch: then according to what the figure of the fracture is, prepare for that.And if the fracture extends to the edge of the spatula, split one edge of the edge of the spatula in two, and cut through the bone with it, and pull off the skin in the direction of the other side.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	And reduce it over its natural figure by any means of ingenuity that is possible for you.And if the fracture does not extend to its edge, but is split in half at one end: cut through the bone and split the skin from the inside out.Then bring the two sides together as far as they will go, and tie them with a ligature.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	Then place over the place flour mill with egg white, and mild poultice, and put on top a little from cloth doubled.And if there is blood in the wound, then put on some egg yolk before the poultice, so that it may congeal over it, and so draw it out when you remove the poultice.And renew this dressing once or twice daily until the fracture is restored.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	Then place over it a wide splint of thin wood according to the quantity of the whole spatula, or larger by a little.And put it on in such a way that its edges are not raised above the edge of the spatula, except a little at one end where it is split.And keep this dressing until the fracture is restored.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	But if there is a hollow under the splint in any place of the spatula, then equalize that hollow with mild poultice until the splint comes down according to its equality.And you may put a few plasters on top of each other, one over another, and renew them once or twice a day, according to what is necessary.Et si concauitas non est in locis Spatulae, sed in astella sola, et non possunt equa illam concauitatem adfundere stuppa leniter: tunc astellam in medio scissuram faciente flecte super concauitatem, donec contiguum sit cum spatula.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	Then tie it from above with a long bandage, with a suitable constriction and firmness of the ligature, until it cannot move out of its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	And consider the ligature every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Whenever therefore the ligature is loosened, tie it and with an equal band if it moves from its place, and let him lie on his side that is healthy.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	And indeed the spatula is restored in twenty days or even twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	When therefore this number is completed, then loose the ligature and you will be secure.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	For it is of bones whose union there is no fear, nor of their separation.Quo autem periculum est, in his quae a membrorum contusionibus sint.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	If however it is a fragment of bone that has protruded and is piercing under the skin, then cut above it and take out the bone.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	And do what we said concerning the fracture of the collarbone from the hot abscess, if something occurs from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	¶ On the restoration of a fractured breastbone
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	The breastbone is sometimes broken in the middle, and that rarely happens.Quod si contigat, adfixus sit ad se ipse per ligaturas, ut diximus in fractura Osi.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	If it does happen, let the two ends be bound together as we said concerning a broken rib.The extremities of it are for the most part broken and crushed from its accidents.Et faciatur super illum, ut diximus in fractura Osi, et melle et oleo et linteo prostrato super eum.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	When that which is in the middle of it is broken, and inclines towards the lower parts, and a painful wound happens to it, and difficulty in breathing, and coughing; and perhaps it emits blood, and a concavity appears in the bone fractured, and is not concealed from sensation, its restoration is, that the invalid should be laid on his back: and place between its spatulas some poultice.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	Then press his shoulders, and draw together his ribs on both sides with your hands; and spread him out to an equal extent, in every way in which it is possible and convenient for him, until the bone returns to its proper shape.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	Then place some poultice and plaster upon him; and put over that a splint of fine willow or hazel, or other similar woods of light weight, after you have enveloped them in linen.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	Then spread it out while binding it over the fractured bone, so that it does not shift; and go about with the ligature several times around to his back in a circular manner, and tighten it decently.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	Then consider the ligature at every hour; and whenever it softens, tighten it. And if necessity compels the removal of it on account of itching, or corrosion which happens in the spot, or pain, or pustule: then hasten, and loosen it, and remove the poultice, and rectify what has happened according to the method of its cure.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	Then restore the poultice if you see that it is necessary; and attach to it a ligature until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	Of the restoration of ribs when they are broken.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.De curatione fracture costarum.
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	Know that a fracture of the ribs does not occur except in thick places which follow the back, and from their ends from the anterior part.Et uidelibet si in locis illa minutis quae sunt super dorsum accidit fractura, et quod est prope extremitatem costarum: illud non facit multum ad dolorem, sed aliter si prope medium ossis, quia illuc convenerunt nervi omnes qui procedunt ex medietate corporis, et illic consistunt.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	And they are not rubbed except because they are cartilaginous.
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	And the knowledge of it is not hidden from the sense in examination with fingers.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	And its restoration is done in such a way that it is as equal as possible to the fracture with fingers, until it equals the shape according to what is necessary.
Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	Then plaster casts, and draw up the broken bone with a splint, if needed by that.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	And if the fracture of the ribs is tilted towards the inside: then acute and painful pain occurs, and puncturing, just as that puncturing which happens to him who has pleurisy; because the bone pricks the membrane, and also it happens to him that there is difficulty in breathing, and coughing, and vomiting of a lot of blood; and this is difficult to heal.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	And now the ancients devised for it with many devices; and among them are those who say to put foods to the patient that generate inflammation and heat, so that the stomach is inflamed, and extended, and the fracture is pushed outward.
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	But we abstain from it, lest it be a cause of an unhealthy ulcer, if it did not happen.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	But if it has already happened, then add to it.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: ponatur super locum uentosa, deinde sugatur cum fortitudine, et est similius ratiocinationi.	And some of them said: put over the place a poultice, and then suck it hard, and that is more reasonable.Et si non uisum est facere puncturam, faciat puncturam, ut facit ad pleuriticam.
Verumtamen timetur, quod attrahat uentosa superfluitates ad locum, propter dispositionem debilitatis.	However, it is feared that the poultice attracts superfluities to the place because of the weakness of the disposition.Et ponantur super eum vestimenta puluara per noctem: et si accidit, ut uelamen inflat et protendatur, faciat puncturam, quod est ad praetensionem.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: oportet ut cooperiatur locus cum lana quae iam submersa est in oleo calido: et ponantur puluilli inter Costas, donec impleatur: ut sit ligatura aequalis quando inuoluis eam secundum rotunditatem.	And some of them said: it is necessary that the place be covered with wool which has already been submerged in hot oil; and that cotton pads be placed between the ribs, until they are full; so that there is an equal bandage when you wrap her according to the roundness.
Deinde curetur infirmus curatione pleuresis ex cibo et medicina.	Then the invalid is cared for by a cure of pneumonia from food and medicine.
Quod si coartat infirmum res uehemens, quam non tolerat, et os pungit uelamen punctura laedente, et timemus super infirmum: tunc oportet, ut scindamus super locum, et detegamus a Costa fracta.	If the invalid constricts from a heavy food which he cannot tolerate, and the mouth is pierced by a sharp tool wounding, and we fear for the invalid: then it is necessary to split over the place, and uncover from the broken rib.
Deinde ponamus super ea instrumentum quod conseruat sifac, cuius rememoratio praecessit: et incidamus os cum facilitate, et incidamus ipsum.	Then we put on her an instrument that keeps the throat, whose reminder precedes; and we pierce the mouth with ease, and we pierce it itself.Et si non possit tollere eam, sed lacu uelato remanserit, oportet eum, qui curat eam, ut curetur curatio puluis: et detur ea in puluem, et ponatur super os.
Deinde aggregemus duo labia uulneris, si est magnum cum sutura: et curemus ipsum cum emplastris, donec sanetur.	And if he cannot bear it, but remains with the wound covered by a bandage, it is necessary for him who cures her, that there be a cure of dust; and let this be given in dust, and let it be put on the mouth.Then we will bring together the two lips of the wound, if it is large with sutures: and let it be cured with plasters, until it heals.
Quod si accidat interim apostema calidum, tunc propera, et infunde puluillos in oleo rosato, et pone super locum: et curetur infirmus cum eo quod conuenit apostemati.	If a warm blister happens in the meantime, then quickly pour cotton pads in rose oil, and put them over the place; and let the invalid be cured with it as befits the blister.Et si fiunt uulnera per contusionem, aut per lacerationem per se: et non possit curari per medicamentum, sed per uentriculi, et per eorum quae in eo sunt: tunc oportet, ut curatur cum eorum, qui fiunt in venter.
Interim etiam resupinetur super latus super quod dormit, donec sanetur.	Let him also recline on his side over which he is sleeping until he is healed.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spondilium dorsi et colli.	Of the restoration of a fracture of the back and neck vertebrae.
Caput X.	Chapter 10:
Ossibus quidem colli quandoque aduenit fractura, et raro accidit eis attritio: et similiter Spondilibus dorsi etiam.	When indeed there is a fracture of the neck vertebrae, and also rarely in the back; likewise with the back vertebrae.
Cum ergo accidit illud alicui, et uis scire, an sanetur, an non sanetur: tunc confidera.	And when this happens to someone, and you wish to know whether it can be healed or not; then consider the following.Si ossia uis pacata esse, et non contraria mortis naturam, sana erunt, si non erunt contraria vitam, nisi consulete medicum experientem.
Nam si uides manus eius iam mollificatas, et stupefactas, et mortuas: et non potest mouere eas, neque extendere eas, neque constringere eas: et quando constringis eas cum digitis tuis, et pungis eas cum acu, non sentit illud, et non sentit in eis dolorem: tunc scias, quia non sanatur, et in pluribus dispositionibus est mortale.	For if indeed you see his hands already soft, and stiff, and dead; and he cannot move them, nor extend them, nor contract them; and when you contract them with your fingers, and prick them with a pin, he does not feel it, and does not feel any pain in them: then know that he will not be healed, and he is in a condition in which death is imminent.
Quod si mouet eas, et sentit in eis constrictionem cum digitis et puncturam: tunc scias, quia nucha ossis salua est, et quod infirmus sanabitur cum curatione.	If indeed he can move them, and feels the contraction with your fingers and the pricking: then know that the neck bone is safe, and that the sick person will be healed with treatment.Et si non potest movere eas, sed sentit constrictionem et puncturam, scias, quia ossa sana sunt, sed nervi mortui.
Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If it meets the spine of its back and you wish to know whether it will be healed or not, then look at its feet. If you see that they have become soft, and the same thing has happened to its hands, when it lies on its back, wind escapes and excrement comes out unwillingly; and when it turns over onto its belly, excrement comes out unwillingly; and when it turns over on its back and wants to urinate but cannot, then you will know that it is mortal.
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	Do not therefore labor at curing it.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	If however nothing of this has happened to it, the case is less serious.
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	The treatment of what has happened to it is that you prepare the sedative of a hot blister, so that you place on the spine a pounded oil of roses alone, or with roasted eggs.
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	Place this on the wound several times a day, until the hot blister is soothed; then place on the spot one of the comforting, drying and tightening plasters; and instruct the patient to use rest and tranquility.
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	Let him not sleep on the part with which he feels pain until it is healed.
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.	If this happens in the abrasion of a bone that is split, or something that has already been separated from it, then you must open up the skin and take away what is there.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, si est magnum, cum sutura.	Then sew together the two lips of the wound if it is large.Et ponas super ipso ligaturam, ut stringat: et post diem, remouescat ligaturam, et consideret locum, sicut facit in apostematis calidi.
Deinde cura ipsum cum aliquo incarnatiuo, ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	And place a bandage on it to tighten it; and the next day, loosen the bandage and look at the spot, just as he does in the case of a hot blister. Then treat it with some ointment until it is healed.
Si uero frangitur postremum ossis alhausos, et est finis caudae: tunc oportet, ut intromittas pollicem manus sinistrae in anum, et aeques os fractum manu altera, secundum quod possibile est, et secunda aequatione.	If however the tail-bone is finally broken off, and this is the end of it, then you must insert your left thumb into the anus and with your other hand seize the broken bone as evenly as possible, and bring them together.
Deinde pone super ipsum, et aufer ipsum: et cura uulnus cum curatione quae praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then put it on top of the wound and remove it; and treat the wound with the treatment that has preceded until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Anchae.	¶ On the restoration of an anchorite.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	It rarely happens that anchorites break bones.Et si in quodam monachorum, vel aliarum personarum, ossa frangantur:
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	And if in any monk or other person, their bones are broken: And if they are broken, then their fracture is not, unless there is comminution at their ends; and they are split lengthwise, and decline towards the bowels; and there occurs a feeble pain in the place, and pricking; and the leg that is broken is stunned.Et illo tempo debet accidere lues et mortis periculum: quod si non curatur, mortalitatem accidere debet.
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius.	And its restoration is that you place your hand upon it until you stand over the fracture in whatever way its figure is.
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali.	If the fracture is only at its ends, then equal that fracture according to what is prepared for you from equality, until it is similar to its natural figure.
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	But if the fracture is along its length, or already inclines towards the insides: then let the invalid lie over his belly, until the restoration of that fracture is prepared for you.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae.	When you have equalized it therefore, place an ointment over it; then place over it a splint of wood or of hide; and tighten the bandage over it, above where you fear the permutation of the fracture, or the removal of the splint.Et quando remouerit astella, tunc fac ut stet super fracturam qualiter est figura eius: donec conficiatur restauratio illius fracturae.
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	And make an equal hollow in them with what fills it, until it fits tightly according to its equality: and tell the patient to sleep on his back or on his healthy side.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	But if a hot blister should occur on him: then cease from extending it and from its restoration until the hot blister is seated; and place upon what sits on it according to how it precedes, then return to his restoration and tighten it as necessary.
Si uero accidit in osse satagie, aut comminuitur, extrahe.	If however it occurs on a bone, or is crushed, extract it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Adiutorii.	The Aid for the Restoration of a Fracture.Take an equal amount of the powder of al-bansoz and mix it with vinegar; and apply plasters to the fractured place until the bone is set in its proper position, then stop applying the plaster and let the patient return to his work when he can bear weight on that part without pain.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.Of Wounds of the Head.If you find a wound of the scalp with the bone exposed, apply a plaster of the powder of al-bansoz and vinegar; then cover it with a bandage of linen or a piece of woolen cloth over it.
Adiutorium est illud, quod est inter cubitum usque ad caput Spatulae.	The aid is that which is between the elbow up to the head of the spatula.Si autem sit in fronte, et capite, extrahe eam cum spatula: donec faciat stigmata.
Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	If however it is on the forehead and head, extract it with a spatula until it makes a mark. If therefore it is broken, then its restoration is according to one of two methods.Si autem sit in fronte, et capite, extrahe eam cum spatulae: donec faciat stigmata.
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	Of these one is to take a piece of flat wood of medium thickness in this form which follows.Secundum hoc iterum, quod sequitur.
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	And the ends are bound with two ligaments.Et sit inter duos ligaturas caput spatulae: et ligatur ad os fractum et al-bansoz applicet super eam, et super eam plastrum de ligno.
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	And the head of the spatula is placed between two ligaments and bound to the fractured bone and al-bansoz is applied over it and a plaster of wood over that; then let him be suspended from an elevated place and let the patient sit on a seat.Et sint duo homines, qui tenentum in manibus suis, et flectant eum ad pedem contra pedem: et ad caput contra caput.
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	Then let two men who hold it in their hands bend him leg against leg and head against head; then he should throw his fractured arm over the wood until he reaches his armpit, in whose middle is attached the curve of the wood.Et sint ultra duodecim homines, qui tenentum eum per duodecim horas, donec sitem: et flectant eum ad pedes contra pedes, et ad caput contra caput.
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	Then suspend something heavy above it so that the assistant will have to reach down below for it.
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	Then the doctor will set the fracture at the same time, until the fracture is reset, as it should be.
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	And another way is that the sick person is laid supine on his neck: and his hand is suspended from his neck with a bandage.
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	Then command two assistants that one of them should hold with his hands what is above the fracture; and that the other should hold below it, and each of them stretch out to his part.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	And if you want the extension to be stronger, then tighten under the fracture with a bandage, and above it with another bandage; and let each of the two assistants stretch out to his part.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	If therefore the fracture is near the extremity of the shoulder joint, then it is fitting that one bandage be placed under the elbow-joint, and another below the fracture turned around the arm.Et deinde ponantur alii ligantes super fracturam usque ad cubitum: et sic, sicut oportet, stringantur omnia haec ligamina.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	And likewise if the fracture is near the elbow; then there ought to be a bandage placed over that place, and one above the elbow also. And in like manner all these bandages are to be bound up tightly.Et si est propinqua titillico: tunc ponatur ligamentum sub illo loco, et supra cubitum.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	Then with ease and without effort reduce the fracture to its proper position until it is reduced as required; then apply a good application and bind it up if there is no hot abscess.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	But if a hot abscess has occurred, then loosen the binding until the seventh day.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	And place over the abscess a piece of wool moistened with vinegar and rose oil until the abscess is quiet; then bind it up. And the manner of binding it up is to put an application over the fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	Then place a folded cloth from new cloth over the application.Et fac eam primum relaxare usque ad primam uiridem, et deinde stringe usque ad ultimam: sed non ita stringas ut opprimatur: sed tanquam si linteum uolueris facias eam: donec quando aduenerit ad bonam consuetudinem.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	Then he should draw up the arm on the side of the helper, and put his hand open over his shoulder.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	And put a cloth and tie over the helper's arm so that the arm stands in its place; if it does not hinder you from doing something, or something is changed on you from the broken bone.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	If you are afraid that something will change on you from the broken bone, then use splints; and it is necessary to put over the fracture itself a splint which is broader and stronger than the other splints.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	And put between each splint the width of a finger; and let the length of the splints be according to the fracture with the addition of three fingers from every part.Et facias astellas in modum pedis, et liges ab extremitate astellae ad extremitatem, et facias ut sint in una linea.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	Then tie tightly over the stars the ligature I mentioned at the beginning of this chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	And it is necessary that your ligature be tighter around the site of the fracture.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	And the more the bone has been elongated, the looser the ligature should be.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	Now if you see that the stars are in position and the ligature is tight as we described, then do this in the hour in which you restore the limb; but if you fear that a hot pustule has formed, then loosen the ligature and the stars until the seventh day, as we have said.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	Then inspect the ligature over the next three days to make sure that there is no itching or swelling in the area and that food can reach the limb freely and not be blocked by a build-up of fluid due to the tightness of the ligature.Si autem uideris aliquid ex his, fac de novo pro parte superius et subligaturum, sicut diximus.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	If you see any of these things, make a new ligature and splint for the part above, as we said. So correct it all according to what we have said.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	But if you are confident that nothing will go wrong then do not loosen the ligature until three or more days have passed.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	Let the patient lie on his back with his hand on his stomach and place a pillow stuffed with wool evenly underneath the elbow.Et facit tali dormitione in nocte, usque post septenarias.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	Let him sleep like this at night for seven nights. And inspect the area frequently during the day and night to make sure that the broken bone does not lose its alignment or the ligature soften.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	So correct it all by your skill.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	And give the patient food according to what we have prescribed, making it very soft at first until his mouth begins to heal; then you can begin to thicken his food.Et facit talia usque post septenarias.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	It is the custom for the helper and the leg to be bound for forty days; then it must be released, and a bath administered, and medicated with ointments that smooth it.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	If the fracture is hideous, abraded: then you do not release from it the bandage and splints for up to fifty days, and up to two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	On the restoration of a fractured arm.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.De fractura humeri.
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	The arm is composed of two bones, which are called the two pigeons.Cum itaque bracium frangerit, primum est ut videas ubi stet fractura: nam si in medio fuere, et non ad extremum, optimus est ut consولي; sed si ad extremum fuere, et non in medio, optimus est ut liges et astelles.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	So when the arm is broken, first you must see where the fracture is located; for if it is in the middle and not at the end, the best course is to set it with a splint; but if it is at the end and not in the middle, the best course is to bind and splint.One of these is small: and it is that which follows the thumb.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	And the other is large, and it is that which is placed below the small one from the lower part.Sed si et in medio et ad extremum fuere fractura: tunc optimus est ut liges, et astellas, sed non consoli.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	The bone of the big toe might be fractured only, or also that of the little toe; or they might both be broken at the same time.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	When therefore a fracture occurs in the little toe above, then its restoration is easy and its healing easier.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	And when the big toe is fractured below, it is a bad fracture, and its healing difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	And it is worse when both bones are broken at the same time.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	If then the bone that is fractured is the little toe above, it behooves the physician at its restoration to apply a slight extension with ease until he makes it even.Et conuenit medicum postea, ut apud sanationem eius faciat flexione paruam cum facilitote, donec perficiat eam, et fiant articulus et ossa sania.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	If indeed it is a large one which has been broken, then it is necessary that he should put on a very strong ligature.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	And it is necessary for him to make the shape of a hand in its restoration and its extension extended over the wound.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	And let the thumb of the hand be higher than all the fingers, and let the joint be lower than all the others or the rest; and let the disabled man sit with his legs squared under him, and let the wound be before him or in front of him, at a distance so that the disabled man does not experience any discomfort.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	Then the assistant should extend the arm from the lower part with his hand or with a ligature.Et si non posset extendi eum per se, tunc ponantur apud brachium ligaturen: et post haec ponatur super ligaturas per se manibus suis uel per alium ministerem: et sic deinde teneantur ligaturae ut possint esse per se in extensionem.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	And another assistant similarly stretch from above.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	Then the physician equalizes the bone, until he reduces it to as good a figure as he can.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	If there are splinters in the fracture of the bone, then try with your strength to reduce every fragment into its place.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	But if you see a splinter separated and piercing the skin, and you have no hope of its restoration: then seek above it and remove it according to the manner which we said in what went before.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	But if the fracture is with a wound, I have already made to that particular chapter, therefore take its cure from there.Et si in uulnere sunt ossa uulnera, et apparet sathaiatum quod non potest reduci: sed tamen speras, quia illa curari poterunt: ergo fac ad illos quod diximus de fractura cum sathaiato intrinsecus.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	But if in the beginning of your restoration an ulcer becomes hot, then line a cloth with cerate made from rose-oil, and white wax, and let it be between the thickness and thinness: and apply the cloth over it with a subtle bandage, until when the ulcer is healed: then remove the cerates, and put on an ointment prepared from miller's powder with egg-white.Et si accidat ut apostema sit frigidum, sed tamen exsudat: et non potes sperare quia curabitur: ergo remoue omnem ceratum, et emplace cum emplastro praeparato ex ligno gurjuni, cum albumine oui et oleum rosati.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	Then put stars, and let there be a star which is placed over the break itself is slightly wider and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	And know that the number of stars in the arm is six in many dispositions, or if it is broken in one joint, or in two joints at the same time.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	Then put your strap above the place of the break stronger and more violent, and somewhat more with strap to the top of the fracture, or to the bottom of it, or put softer strap strap slightly, according to what precised reminder it in the beginning of the chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	And are the sheets which wrap around the break, soft sheets, wet: and are not hard, rough.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	And let the thread with which it is bound from flax proper, middle between thin and thick, as we narrated.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	And consider the limb and ligament after days.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	If something happens that the correction is necessary, as pruritus which happens to the member: then it is necessary, so that you embrocate the member with warm water, until that pruritus quiets, and you leave the member not constricted, until he quiets, then repeat the strap.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	If the strap is now softened, and the bone is now removed, and similar to those: then rectify it all by your strength, and consider again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	For if nutrition is prohibited to come to the limb because of the excess of the strap, then it is necessary that you soften it slightly, and let go of it for several days, until it flows to it nutrition, then tighten it.Et scias quod oportet te illud totum rectificare, cum uirtute tua, donec quiescat ille pruritus et dolus qui in membrum accidit, donec quiescat: et ne dimittas membrum in multum, nisi rectificatus sit ille pruritus: et fac ut siemens illius non disiungatur.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	If, however, nothing of what we have mentioned happens to the sick person, then he does not need to be bled unless after twenty days or about that time.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	Then the hand of the patient is raised up to his neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	And let his neck be even and be guarded by its strength from agitated movements.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	And let him sleep on his back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	And you shall know that this fracture is restored within thirty days or thirty-two days; and perhaps it is restored within eighteen days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	All of this is according to the dispositions of complexions, and the dispositions of strength.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	Of the restoration of fractures in the hand.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	Know that rarely does a fracture occur to the bones of the hand or the joints of the fingers.Et est difficilis restauratio eorum.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	And it does not happen to him unless he is often rubbed.Et si acciderit fractura in pectino Manus:
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	When therefore, there happens a fracture of the tibia, or dislocation; then it is necessary that the invalid should sit in a square chair; and in front of him be another seat according to equality.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	Then place his hand on it stretched out.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	Then the assistant lengthens the fractured bones and makes them equal, while the physician holds them until they are joined with a good joint.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	Then it is necessary that he put on a plaster and poultice, if no hot ulcer appears.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	Then place a splint over it according to the quantity of the place; and you have already enveloped it in a linen cloth.
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	But if the fracture is around the lower part of the tibia, then make a similar ball out of cloth; and order the invalid to press it with his fractured leg; then bind it tightly with a long bandage.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	And let the splint be of leather, in which there is flexibility, so that the leather may apply with the body of the tibia; and tie it, according as it ought to be tied.Et habeat astellam aliquem ad latus eius plantae: et sic faciatur de contraria parte.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	But if the fracture is on the outside, then it is necessary: to put a splint over that, and another splint from below the leg; and let the hand be open and straight.Et sic faciatur de contraria parte. 
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	Then apply a splint as you would to the hand and extend it with a bandage between the fingers.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	If any of the joints of the fingers is broken, then if it is the thumb, it is set straight according to what is appropriate.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	Then the wound is bandaged with the palm and if you like, a small, straight splint is put on it so that the fracture is soothed and not moved.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	If, however, the fracture is on one of the other fingers -- middle, index, ring or little finger -- then it is set and bound to a healthy finger next to it; or all are bound according to their arrangement and this is better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	Or put on top of the splint, a small one as we said above for the thumb.Quod si accidat fractura cum commotione, et vna, aut plures ossa de pedis, utrumque faciatur: scilicet ligetur cum pediere sano: vel ligentur omnia ossa pro parte: et sic agantur ut antea diximus.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	And consider in your restoration, and after the disposition of the hot apostema: and oppose with it what is appropriate, when something happens to him, according to how his narrative is iterated.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	Of the restoration of a broken hip.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.De restoratione Fracturae cranii.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	The hip-bone is often broken and made manifest to the sense: because it turns inward and backward.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	And its restoration is thus, that a ligament is tied above the fracture, and another ligament below the fracture.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	And the invalid be stretched out on his face.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	Then the attendant must stretch every ligament to its own part according to its equality: and this when the fracture is in the middle of the bone.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	But if the fracture be near the root of the hip-bone, then let there be a ligament to the side of the comb, that the extension may fall upward; and another ligament below the fracture.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	And thus similarly if the fracture is near the knee, then let there be a ligament near the knee, that the extension may fall to the lower parts.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	Then the physician equalizes the bone with his two hands, until he reduces it according to the similarity of its natural figure: and the bone is joined by a good junction.Et postea sint ligaturen ad utramque partem pro consilio medicus.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	Then it is necessary that you put a plaster and a bandage if there does not occur a blister on the limb.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	If it happens that a blister occurs on it; then leave it for several days, until the blister is cooled, and then return to your cure.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	The bandage of this however is as follows:
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	It is necessary that you wrap around the break a hard padding, that is, a bandage, and double it twice or three times, and let there be superfluity from it.Et si forte suppurationem habuerit, non debet ibi ponere emplastrum.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	Then envelop the leg, until the heel is healed at its root.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	And insert a long thread between the hip and the leg near the knee to the lows, and let the ends of the thread come from the upper part of the two parts.Et liges per omnia filum: et facies ligaturam, si placet.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	Then return over the breast and rib cage what is superfluous from food.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	Then put on the thigh in the place of its fracture stars, and put out of them a star on the shin bone.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	Then fill the emptiness between the thigh and hip with soft cloth, so that it is even in tension.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	Then begin with strong tension from the middle over the place of fracture three turns, or four.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	And the more you are stretched with ligament away from the site of fracture, the lesser your tension and softer and gentler it is.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	Then attend to both ends of thread which you have inserted between hip and thigh.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	Therefore tie with both three stars that are above.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	Then walk with two ends of thread to the bottom until you reach ankle bone.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	And with both tighten the ends of stars from other part: that ligament does not move out of its place.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	Then loosen tension over it while remaining, so that no corrosion happens to member, nor blister, nor inflammation and similar to them.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	If anything happen from that.
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	Therefore hasten with solution of it and correct all that happened therefrom completely according to what we said many times.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	If in bone is a splinter of bone which pricks: then it behooves you to even that if it is possible for you.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	And if not, find over it and remove it and care with whom its predecessor remembered until healed.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	And whenever this fracture of hip tightens, beyond which added to it stars, as we said in support and arm.
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	However in restoration of it so broken, not happened to the lame claudication.Et si postea ueniat ad te: quod est inter coxam et crura, uellebat ut remoueret astellam super osse.
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	And if later comes to you: that which is between hip and thigh wanted as removed a star on bone. And if restored alone, beyond which applied to it another thigh, then necessary, as lames he whose is always.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.
