And you should know that the hip is contracted within fifty days or a little added or lessened: all this according to the diversity of complexions and other dispositions.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	And also in the restoration of a broken kneecap.
Caput XVI.	CHAPTER 16.
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	You should know that a fracture of the kneecap rarely happens, but attrition to it occurs often.Et si acciderit fractura, est necesse, ut antequan tu commiseris ad restitutionem, quod cognoscas, an irruhit in intrinsecum, an extrinsecum.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	If however a fracture does occur, then it is necessary that before you proceed to restoration, you should find out whether the break has occurred inwards or outwards.And if indeed a fracture occurs, then there will be either a fissure, or an aperture in its parts.Et si irruhit intrinsecus, tunc debes eandem subdere ad latera, et tenere cum fascibus.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	And it is with a wound and without a wound.
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	And one stands over it altogether with feeling.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	And its restoration is thus, as to make equal that which is disrupted from its parts with fingers, until it is gathered together and joined according to what is possible out of equality and ease, and skill.
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	Then put a plaster from sesame seed flour, or of miller's bran, with white of egg; and place over it a round pad, if you need these: and tie it up over that with a suitable bandage.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	Then consider all the dispositions which we have narrated in other fractures; like a hot blister, and similar to that: thus, so as you oppose every accident with it that suits it, until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	Of the restoration of a broken Leg.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.De fractura ossis cruris in genere et eius curatione.
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	Know that there are two bones of the leg, one is thick and is called by the name of the leg, and the other is thin and is called the shank.
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	And with both kinds of fractures that happen to these two bones of the leg happen as they do to the two bones of the arm; and because of this their restoration happens in the same way as the restoration of the arm, and the operation is one.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	If both bones are broken at the same time, the leg is turned to all parts.Et si non possit tollere pedem, sed debet stare cum Cruce ad terram, sed non debet stare super Crucem, quia ossa non sint connexa: et sic debet stetire donec restaurentur ossa, et postea debet ambulare secundum consilium medicus.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	And if only the thinner bone is broken, the leg turns to the front part. And if he cannot take away the foot, but must stand with his leg to the ground, yet he must not stand on it because the bones are not connected; and thus he should lie until the bones are restored, and afterwards he should walk according to the advice of the doctor.And if only the thicker bone is broken, the leg turns to the back part.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	And if the thicker bone is broken, you will find it below; and it is from among those which do not conceal themselves from you.Quod si est fractura in medio ossi, et non possunt esse connecta, sed debent essere disjuncta: et sic debet stetire donec restaurentur, et postea ambulare secundum consilium medicus.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	Then apply the extension, and the equalization, and the ligation of the stars in accordance with that equally.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	However, if the fracture is a foul fracture, having many small pieces: let there be less extension and gentler reduction by you.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	And in the leg indeed there is something from the operation on the arm: and it is, as when you equal the stars, and complete all your operation, then take two bands of wood of the pine, which is administered in the making of beds that is placed under boards: and they are made from spatulas of palm: and choose from among them which has small thickness, and not of minute ones: and let the length of them be according to the length of the leg from the knee down below.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	Then wrap over each band two windings according to its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	And put one part of the leg from one side, and the other from the other side: and let them be from the knee down to the foot.Et fac ut sint in medio, et super pedem pedalis ad modum ligaturae: et fac ut sint ad modum ligaturae in medio.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	Then tie together two of the aponeuroses in three places, from both ends and the middle.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	For when constriction is prohibited, the leg inclines to the right and left, and it stands in a good position.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	And indeed let there now be administered a couch of wood according to the length of the leg, and let the leg be placed on it so that it might preserve itself from motion.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	And indeed you must above all make this when with it there is a proper wound.Quod si non facietis et cum ea manebit vulnus, deinde iterum factus cruoris motus in eo dispendietur omnia.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	Then consider the leg every day and try to treat it with the final cure from apostematous, or inflammation, or other diseases.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	If one of these things happens to it, then treat it with what is appropriate until it gets better if God wills it.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	On the fracture of bones of the foot and the fingers.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.De fractura Metatarsi.
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	The calcaneus does not suffer a complete fracture at all.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	And the bones of the foot are sometimes broken, and the toes are scarcely ever broken, and they do not happen but by attrition in many dispositions.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	And if it happens that the bones of the foot are broken, and you see these bones rise up one above another, then let the sick person set his foot on the ground as he walks.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	Then stand and put your foot over that which rises from those bones; afterwards press, or trample it down: and make it even, until it return to its place.Si autem non possit pedem ponere super terram, et uides ossa eleuata super se non redeunt ad locum suum, sed permanet in uno: accipito linteo puluero, et stantibus ossibus, subtege illos per omnia: postea trahe eam linteam usque ad extremum pedis.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	But if he cannot set his foot on the ground, and you see the bones rise up above one another and do not return to their place, but remain in one; take some lint, and while the bones are standing, cover them all over: afterwards draw this lint as far down as the extremity of the foot.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	Then bind it with a decent ligature around the foot, after you have enveloped it with rags, and other things as is needed.Si autem ossa illius Pedis non possunt stetere in locis suis, neque redeunt ad locum suum: ponat eam super tabulam et paulo plus altam a terra, donec resituitur ad locum suum, et non sicut est ante fracturam.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	But if the bones of that foot cannot stand in their places, nor return to their place: let him set it on a board, a little higher from the ground, until it is restored to its place, and not as it was before the fracture.And when three or four days have passed, then loosen the ligature.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	For you will find that they are equalized, whether they be broken, or displaced.Et cum erunt equiati, ponat super illos emplastri et stuppam, nec uellem, ne commota rursus rediant ad locum suum: postea faciat, ut ambulet per tres dies vel quatuor, et stetit in uno loco, sed non dormiat ibi.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	The operation is therefore performed on them as you see.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	If however some fingers are broken then restore them and make them even according to what I have narrated to you in the restoration of the fingers of the hand.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	Then put your finger on the splint according to the length of the finger and make it a little wider; then put under the foot this board which I have narrated to you and tighten it with a suitable bandage.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	If however that which is broken consists of two bones or three, or more, then put on top of every finger a splint of its own size, wrapped in linen; and tighten the board under the foot and let it stand above one head of the board outside the instep so as to hold good with a grip.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	And it behooves you not to forget but to consider all that I have said to you about other fractures from the accidents which we have discussed and oppose every accident with what is fitting.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	Of the fracture of the pubic bone, the breast-bone and the spear-bone in a man.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	When the pubic bone of a woman is broken then let her sit square.Et ponat super os patellarum tabulam, et lintea super tabulam: uti dixi tibi in fractura ossium manu.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	Then tip her slightly toward her back and hold her from behind.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	Then the midwife should fill her vagina with an instrument until she is completely full; and a lump should be made in her vagina like a ball.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	Then the woman is shaken, and her back is gradually lifted.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	For that instrument will come out, until in front of the door of her vagina there is made like a ball, and the opening split.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	Then put a little poultice on her back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	When she wants to urinate, remove the instrument with ease, then let her urinate; and return the instrument in the way you put it in at first; then return to the poultice first.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	Let her do that for seven days or around there; for the opening is restored.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	And if you want, take a feather of an ostrich, and tie it over the hole with a reed pipe, and insert the whole feather into her vagina.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	Then blow into the pipe with force, until the feather is inflated inside her vagina; for the opening will be split again.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	Then let it be filled with an instrument, and let it stand for several days, according to what we narrated; until she is healed.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	And when the bone of a man or woman is broken, then prepare for its restoration and its setting that which we narrated about the bone of the ankle.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	And do not conceal the anus with these close fractures, which seldom happen, especially to one who has some study or use.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	And understand my book this much, for the fracture itself indicates to you in many dispositions a straight path in its restoration and its constriction; understand therefore.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	But when the wand of a man is broken, take a goose's throat, and insert the throat into him.Deinde suffla per eam, donec infletur, et reduc eam.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	Then blow through it until it is inflated, and return the throat. Then place over him a bandage of cloth, and let him be bandaged, and sent away for three days, or around that; and he will be healed, if God wills.And if the fracture goes to the bone, then prepare a poultice from the fat of a sheep, and put it on the wound, and wrap it in linen, and bind it with an elastic bandage, and let him be sent away for three days, or around that; and he will be healed, if God wills.And know that this poultice is suitable for all fractures.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	Of the restoration of a broken bone, when there is also a wound.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	It is fitting for him who has a broken bone with a wound, especially if it is a large one, as of the hip or helper, or similar to it, that you apply leeches at once, and phlebotomy: if they attest to you the conditions of phlebotomy, as we have mentioned before.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	If the wound discharges blood, then it is necessary for you to hasten to cut off its flow, in such a way that you powder over it powdered alum, if no other is present.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	Then begin to restore the broken bone on that same day: and do not put off doing so, unless there has been a pustule.Quod si accidit apostema, tene precautionem circa fracturam usque ad diem tertium vel quartum, ut videas, an apostema uelutiatur in illo spatio: nam si non facit, sed mox urit et dolit, tunc scis certe, quod non uitur urere et dolere nisi fractura restiterit.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	If a hot pustule occurs then cease restoration of it until the ninth day so that the pustule may rest.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	And do not approach it on the third day and altogether on the fourth for you would make bad accidents happen to it.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	But if a broken tooth is protruding beyond the flesh then you must try to bring it back and level it off with your hands gently and with little extension.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	If its extension and leveling cannot be done by hand then reduce it using this instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And there is an instrument that is made of iron whose length is seven or eight finger widths and whose breadth is according to the size of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	And because of this it is necessary for the doctor to take three or four of them according to what he needs from them to cure from every kind of fracture.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	And let it be round and have a small thickness so that it does not double over during the compression upon it at the time of operation and its edge be sharp with an edge on its ends.Et sit utilius si fit de ferro frigido: et non debet esse flexile nec fragile, sed placide firmum ad compressionem ad modum quod descripsit supra.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	And it be above that according to its thickness from its middle to its inferiors.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	It is necessary in This Operation, that there be placed the pointed acute end over the prominent end of the bone; and drive it with all its strength, until such time as the bone returns and becomes equal in a certain equality.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	Therefore try to make equal the ends of the fracture in one another.Et si non possit per uigoram equari, ponantur super eam ligatures et tenentur ita donec aequentur:
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	And if the end of it be broken sottil, and take not the instrument well, then is it needful to cut off the end of that bone, until the instrument have hold of it.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	But if you cannot bring them together with that which we have said altogether, then cut it with any of the saws of which we have spoken; or saw it with one of whatever kind it be possible for you.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then scrape off that which remains in the bone from roughness and minute bark.Et si facies cum Incisore, facias per modum qui diximus: idest primum in medio ponas extremitatem instrumenti, et deinde illum sublimes ad latera, donec equari possit.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	When therefore a bone is reduced and the patient feels intense pain after its reduction, then know that the bone has not returned to its natural place.
Fac ergo illud.	Then do thus.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	For you put a great splint upon the patient when you complete your restoration of the bone which you have done.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then immerse the cloth in the astringent wine, the black one.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	And especially if it is in summer.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	And do not place over the wound any linen cloth nor anything in which there is oil, lest it cause putrefaction and corruption to happen in it.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	Then administer pills in an hour after your restoration of the bone.Et pon super uulnus, post quaecunque facies, linteum quod non habet olea: sed si quid olei in eo est, et uino stiptico.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And leave the wound uncovered: so that you may cut with tweezers a hole in the bandages according to the quantity of the wound.Et fac ut non resit lintea.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	And beware of every precaution, lest you constrict the wound with a fracture.Et cuntur lintea in medio ossis cum linteis subditis in iisdem et teneatur cum fasce ut non movatur.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	For many times have foolish doctors done this and brought upon their patients either death or corruption, or a ulceration, that is to say, a foul sore.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	And if your contraction be soft and gentle, differing from the rest of the contractions of other fractures.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	If the wound is bad or great and you fear some of the bad accidents we have narrated, and you feel pain in the affected spot, then you must not put splints on it.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	And make for them bandages out of hard cloths in place of splints and tighten them with these.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	When a day or two have passed and you see the wound beginning to suppurate then remove from above it the bandage which you put on with wine.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	Then apply lint and ointments with which it is our custom to treat wounds such as the ointment called tetrapharmacon and others like it.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	And it is necessary that you loosen the binding.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	And consider the wound every day in the morning and cleanse it until it is consolidated and healed.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	And it is necessary that the limb be prepared thus so that the pus may flow out of it easily.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	If many days pass over the wound and it does not consolidate nor is the pus cut off from it then you should know that there are small pieces of bone there.Quo facto oportet ut inuas per accensas laminas auri, cum eis super locum, et facias illic cauterio: donec sanguis fluat per eum, et postea ueluti abscindere pus.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	For this reason it is necessary to enquire into the wound with a probe.Et si tentas in locis, ubi est dolor, et senseres, quod ibi ossa sunt fracta: tunc facias cauterium.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	If however when you probe in the places where there is pain and you feel that the bones are broken then make a cautery there.So many of these small pieces as are separated from it remove them and pull them out.Quod si non possis omnes extrahere, sed quoscas superi: tunc facies illic unctionem cum unguento tetrapharmaco intra, et per omnia loca, ubi sunt fracta ossa.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	If you cannot remove them all but some remain on top then make an ointment with tetrapharmacon within it and smear it over all the places where the bones are broken.And if any of these remain unseparated, and sting the limb, and cause pain to happen, try to cut them off in whatever way possible for you.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	If it happens that the wound is lacerated or punctured, that is, a ulcer, or of some other form of corruption and putrefaction: then one should oppose to each of them what suits him out of those things which are convenient to cure, the narrative of which precedes in its chapter.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And from that in which it is fitting that my speech should stand, and to which you make your mind present when the bone is broken, and stands out above the limb, just as in the hip-bone, and the helper, and similar to these in great limbs, it is, that you do not suppose its attraction; for very often death has happened from it, indeed leave it until it putrefies.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	Indeed perhaps it will fall off by itself after twenty days or thirty.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	Then therefore cure the wound, if it appears to you; and if not, leave it.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	¶ Of the cure of a Knot in the sole of the foot from a fracture.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	Many times this Knot happens in the sole during the healing of a fracture.Et si post uiginti dies, aut post triginta non uaderit, et tamen ualuit uulnus, sed non curat, quia uulnus non est curatum usque in osse, sed in cutis multum, sed in osse paulum.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	Especially that which is near the joints; and it is discolored out of that figure of the member.Et ista Nodatio multoties pernicieo facit pedem, aut uerticem, quia non curatur osse ad summum: et praecipue si prope iuncturas.
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	And perhaps it will prevent the limb from its natural function.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	And consider then, if the wound is recent: apply to it medicines that cause constriction, such as aloe, frankincense, myrrh, and mastic, and acacia, and those similar to them.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	So that you may receive from these some or all of them: and mix them with wine that constricts, or with the white of an egg, or with vinegar; and place them on the wound in a poultice, and bind them over it with a good bandage.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	And leave off the bandage, not removing it for many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	Then loosen it, and repeat another, until the wound is healed.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Or bind over it a plate of lead decently.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	For lead has the property of removing everything that is feared from the limbs.Et postea fac ut sanguis fluat, et tunc solva stringentem laminam.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If, however, the wound has become a ulcer, and is hard, and quickly calls for removal: then find on it, from its upper part, the prominent overabundance, or scrape it with some razors, until it is healed; and care for it, until it is cured.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	¶ Of the cure when it is restored, and the limb remains after that subtle, not according to its nature.Et quod est subte, si remanserit in ipso, nec possit esse sublato: tunc scies quod ille non potest esse restauratus ad statum sui prioris.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When a bone fracture is restored and the limb remains slender and weak afterwards, then it happens for many reasons.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	One of which is the abundance of solution and bandaging of the ligament not according to what is appropriate; or because of the excess of binding of the ligaments until it prevents nourishment from flowing into the limb; or because of the excess of superfluous embrocation at an improper time; or because of the lack of blood in the body of the sick person, and their weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	And its treatment is to feed the sick person, and make his body tender until blood multiplies in it.
Et administra balneum.	And give him a bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And bring joy and happiness to him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then put pitch on the limb, so that the pitch will attract much nourishment to itself.Et facies illud pro certis diebus, donec redit in statum suum.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	And you shall continue his embrocation with warm water until nourishment runs and he returns to his natural figure.Et quaerito me et inveniabitur medicina salutaris: quia non est medicina super terram.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	¶ On the cure of bone fractures when they are restored crookedly.Cum est fractura ossis in membru, et restat tortuosum post curam: tunc non debet fieri, nisi propter multitudine solutionis et ligaturae eius, quod non fuit secundum artem.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.Et cum facit apoplexia in membrum, et restat tortuosum post illud: tunc debet fieri propter multiplicatio sanguinis super locum fracturas.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When a limb has a fracture, and it remains crooked after healing; then it ought not to be, unless because of the abundance of solution and bandaging of it, which was not according to art.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	And now there are many stupid doctors and restorators who have done that in our land.Quod autem oportet ut facias, quoniam restat tortuositas in membru post sanationem eius: primum fac resorptionem per embrocationes calidas, et applica super locum, ubi est nodatus ossis fracto: et per illum locum quaerere debes, ut facias resorptionem.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	This indeed is a most reproachful operation, leading to death, or great fear, so that it may be mortal.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	But if the lameness and swelling are recent: then it is appropriate that this should be embrocated with warm water in which have been decocted softening herbs, such as the leaves of alder, and its root, and melilot, and similar things.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And let an ointment be made with a softening plaster, as decently prepared dyachilon.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	Or let the mucilage of the root of alder be taken, and pounded with chicken fat, or sesame oil; and let it be plastered with that.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	Or let the fat figs be taken, and rubbed with pigeon dung, and similar things which are named out of medicines diminishing consolidation.Et si postea reserationem non facit, utpote mortuam, sed vivam: tunc oportet, ut emungatur sanguis e parte superius, sicut supra dictum est de claudicatione.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	And if afterwards it does not make a break, as being dead, but alive: then it is fitting that blood be let from the upper part, as above said about lameness. And sometimes the swelling is loosed with continual and gentle friction, which is done with moist hands.Et postea faciatur embrocatio cum aqua tepida et melle.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	And the movement of the limb be directed to every part at all hours.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	And if the crookedness has already gone past and become strong, and turned to stone, and brought on the necessity of cure with iron: then it behoves that above it be cut, and the continuity of the bone be dissolved, and that which flows out of the nodulation or bone with fine instruments be cut; and ease be applied to it with care and effort.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	Of speech in dislocation.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the departure of any joint from its proper place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Why it is prohibited from its own movement, and the shape of the limb is disgraced.Et oportet ut curatur per motus.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And it behooves that it be cured by movements.And it makes happen over the weak pains and violent injuries.Et debet curari ad omnem partem, donec reducatur in locum suum.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	When therefore a dislocation happens to anyone, then it is necessary to hasten its restoration, and not at all delay it.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if it be delayed, the place will mortify, and perhaps with it the reduction of the dislocation.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Hence it is not proper that it should be moved or extended for an hour after the mortification has set in.Quo facto, si ad manum suam reducit dislocationem, postea debet applicare unguentum cum oleo olivo vel lardo ad instar unctorum nostrorum, quod antea dictum est; et postea faciat plastrum super eam, ut antea dictum est.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For very often it makes spasms and painful wounds to happen.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when this happens, then you ought to hasten to let blood from the patient.Et postea facias eum bibere aquam caldagines, et mitte eum in tepidum balneum.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then let him drink warm water and go into a warm bath.Thereafter let him be dismissed until the mortification has subsided.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then let the limb be fomented with hot water and oil.Et postea facias eum bibere sucum de radice gentiana, et melle, et vinum tepidum libenter.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	And then let him drink the juice of the root of gentian, and honey, and warm wine freely.Then let it be reduced with ease.Et postea facias eum bibere sucum de radice gentiana, et melle, et vinum tepidum libenter.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And then let every limb be treated with it whose memory will occur in its own place.Quod si non possit omnino reduxi, tunc debet dimitti ad requiem donec quiescat apostema et dolores eius; et deinde redire ad te.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I have indeed already arranged the chapters on dislocation, also according to what preceded in fracture, from the upper part of the body down to its lower part.Et nunc venio ad capitula de iis quae fiunt per spasmum.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	And now I come to the chapters on those things which happen through spasms.
Caput XXV.	CHAPTER XXV.Of the cure of a dislocation of the lower jaw.Si autem dislocatur mandibula inferior, et non potest reduci, sed tardius manet in uno loco:
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	But if the lower jaw be dislocated and cannot be reduced, but persists in one place for a long time:The two jaws are rarely dislocated.Namque si per spasmum dislocata sit, non debet tardare omnino ad reduci.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the dislocation of both happens in one or two ways.Si namque per spasmum dislocatur, tunc debet curari cum unguento et oleo olivo, vel lardo, vel cum alio unguento ad instar unctorum nostrorum.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or they are moved from their places by a slight movement and slightly softened.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are completely dislocated until they are softened to the chest, until the saliva of the sick person flows and he cannot hold it in, nor can he close his mouth, and his tongue is wrapped with his speech.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	When this dislocation is slight, then it returns to its many dispositions by itself with a little difficulty.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	But if it is a complete dislocation, then the reduction of it should be administered quickly and not delayed at all: and there is the minister holding the head of the sick person; And the doctor puts one hand's index finger into the root of the jaw dislocation between his teeth, if the dislocation is on one side.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he inserts two thumbs at the same time if it is dislocated in two places.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And his other fingers are outside, with which he levels it.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And instruct the sick person to clean and finish his jaws for eating on all sides.Et debet medicus ire per locum dislocationis cum digitibus manuum suarum, et uolgere et inuolvere inter Mandibulas et palatos eius donec redierunt ad locum suum primo: non debet autem perire, neque dolere infirmo.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the physician shall bring the jawbone to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	And if it be difficult to bring it back, especially if both the jawbones are together; then apply heat with hot water and oil, until they are easily reduced; nor delay their reduction altogether, as we have said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	And when they are brought back and made equal, and the wound of the sick person is closed and not opened again; then place on them some small pieces of linen, with a plaster that is made from wax: and rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then it must be bound up easily with soft ligatures.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let the sick person sleep on his back; and let his head be kept steady between two pillows, so that he may not move it to the right or left; nor should he be made to chew anything: rather let there be given him easy food to sip, until when the pains are removed, and the jawbone is set; then let him eat what he will, and let what is administered be given to him with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He must not labour hard at eating, drinking, yawning and speaking, until the jawbone is set and healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If it be difficult to bring back the two jawbones, when they are dislocated and do not return to their places; then many times there arise from this fever and constant pain; and perhaps the sick person's belly is loosed, and perhaps he vomits pure bile.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When you see this happening; then know that it is a destruction, and often the person who suffers it dies within ten days.And if he lives longer than this, yet the man is maimed.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	Of the reduction of the dislocation of the collar bone and the end of the shoulder blade:Et medicus equitet uram, et impellat illum donec redeat ad locum suum, si possit.
Caput XXVI.	And the physician shall bring the collar bone to its place, and if he can't then:CHAPTER XXVI.Of the dislocation of the collar bone, and that at the end of the shoulder blade.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The collar bone indeed does not become dislocated from within; on account of its connection with the breastbone.Sed saepe fit dislocatio in parte externa lateris, scilicit ubi incongrua est articulatio humerorum cum scapula.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it is sometimes dislocated towards the outside; and it is made sensible of this.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is, that he lies feeble upon his back, and extends his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then contract the place with the palm of your hand strongly, for it will return.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then put upon it a plaster, and little bandages, and bind it tightly.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	But the extremities that follow the elbow, and are continued with it, are not dislocated, unless seldom.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	What if it is dislocated on some day: then it behoves, that it be reduced and made equal according to what we have said, and that which you have prepared for yourself.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then put upon it a plaster, and little bandages, and a tight bandage.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And command the sick person to adhere to rest and stillness, until he is cured.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And with this same cure the extremity of the shoulder is reduced, when it is also separated from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	Of the reduction of the dislocation of the shoulder-joint.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	Know that the shoulder-joint is not dislocated except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	Of which one is, that it be dislocated towards the side of the armpit on the lower side.Secundus autem modus est, dislocationis Humeri, quod dislocatur ad exteriora.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second mode is, of the dislocation of the shoulder-joint, that it be dislocated towards the breast side.The third mode is, that it be dislocated upwards.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it is dislocated to the upper part of the shoulder; and this happens seldom.Hic autem est modus, ut dislocetur in humero, quod debet reduci.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	Here then is the way that it be dislocated in the shoulder-joint, which must be reduced.And it is not dislocated to the back, because of the spatula.Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it is sometimes dislocated towards the outside; and it is made sensible of this.And it is not dislocated to the front, because of the nerve.Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And it is very often displaced and pushed towards the lower part of the chest; this happens especially with those who have little flesh on their bodies.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Because it comes out quickly in them and enters quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But with those who have a lot of flesh on their bodies, the opposite is true; that is, it comes out with difficulty and enters with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens to some people that they are hit or fall and the elbow is swelled with a hot swelling, and it is thought because of this that it is already dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	So you should test it until you are certain about it, and then proceed with its cure.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And the dislocation is known when it is towards the lower part of the chest; and you should distinguish between a dislocated elbow and a healthy one.Et quilibet medicus, qui cognoscit Titillum, et scit, quae sint signa titillique dislocati, procedat ad curam eius: sed si non cognoscit hunc modum, teneat manum, et curet per experientiam.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find a clear difference between them, and you will find a hollow in the head of the elbow, and below the titillus at the touch, the head of the elbow as if it were an egg: and the weak person cannot bring their hand back to their ear, nor move it with all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And likewise, if it is dislocated towards the chest or upwards: then you will find a clear touch, and it will not be hidden.Et si quaestus est sub titillico quasi caput humeri ouum sit, et concauitati habet, sic scito, quod dislocatur ad inferos uersus; sed superius concauitas: nam in dislocatione superioris uersus est infima concauitas.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And the reduction of this dislocation is easy when it is recent, or the child is feeble.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction consists in the attendant's raising his hand above him.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then place your thumbs under his chin, and raise the joint forcefully upwards to its place: and the attendant raises his hand, and extends it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then let him lower it, for it will quickly return.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	But if it does not return by the means which we said above, and many days have passed since the beginning of the dislocation, then it is necessary to bathe the invalid in hot water, and to apply a fomentation which softens and soothes, as if one were to steep roots of alder, fenugreek, and sweet lupine in water, and to apply.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then let the invalid lie on his back, and place under his chin a ball of wool and cotton, which is equal in softness and tightness.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the physician shall place his heel upon the ball, and raise the head of the humerus with force, and draw the hand of the invalid downwards.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another attendant shall hold the head of the invalid, so that it does not move downwards: for it will return at once.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you like, reduce it according to the way just described; and it is, that you make a man who is taller than the invalid be present, and let him stand on one side, and thrust his humerus under the chin of the invalid: and raise his chin upwards, until the invalid hangs in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another attendant shall draw the hand of the invalid downwards to his belly.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	But if the invalid is light: then it is necessary that something else be suspended with him, so as to weigh him down; for the dislocation returns at once.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And it is reduced also according to another way; and it is, that a long wood be fixed in the ground, whose head is round in shape, like the rim of a mortar: which is not thick, nor thin.Et ponatur infirmus super caput ligni: et trahatur ad inferiora: et eleuetur titillicus eius ad superiora per uirum qui stet adversum.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then put under the patient some soft wooden beams, after he is laid on his back with his head raised; and let him stand according to the length of the wood.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then his hand is drawn down from the other side, and his body is stretched to the other side with force; for the joint returns quickly to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	If it is difficult to bring him back by all that we have said, then use this treatment: and there is that you take a wood whose length is the amount of two cubits, and its width is the amount of four fingers, and its thickness is the amount of two fingers; which has a round head, so as to alleviate its entry into the deep tickling, according to this form.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then bind over the round head soft cloths, so that it does not hurt the patient's wood.Postquam ergo ponatur sub eum lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum: et ligentur super caput eius panni lenes: et ligantur pedes eius ad extremitatem ligni: et ligentur bracchia eius ad extremitatem ligni ad latere altero.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	After that he is placed under a wood whose length is the amount of two cubits: and they bind soft cloths over his head; and they bind his feet to the end of the wood; and they bind his arms to the end of the wood on the other side.Then let him be placed under the tickling of the patient, so that he may extend his hand or arm over the wood to the bottom; and let the wood be bound over the helper and the arm and the tip of the hand.Postquam ergo ponatur sub eum lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum: et ligentur super caput eius panni lenes: et ligantur pedes eius ad extremitatem ligni: et ligentur bracchia eius ad extremitatem ligni ad latere altero.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	After that he is placed under a wood whose length is the amount of two cubits: and they bind soft cloths over his head; and they bind his feet to the end of the wood; and they bind his arms to the end of the wood on the other side.Then let him be laid with his arm along the rung of a ladder for its breadth, and let his hand be extended down, and let the rest of his body hang from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	For the joint goes in at once.Et sic facies cum titillico super extremitatem pedis: et extendes per omnia corpus eius ad altum, usque dum venit ad locum suum.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	And so you will do with the tickling over the tip of the foot; and you will extend his whole body upwards as far as possible, until it comes to its place.When therefore its entrance is completed in any way possible: then it is necessary that you put a sphere equal in size made of wool under the tickling.Et ponatur sub titillicum panna lenis, ut non laedatur infirmus per spheram lanae: et ligentur pedes eius super extremitatem titilli, et ligentur bracchia eius ad extremitatem titilli.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then put on a plaster of the powder of the mill with frankincense and egg white over the entire shoulder as it is revealed above.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then tighten under the armpit a suitable ligature; and the bandage over the plaster is wrapped on top of it; and his hand is attached to his neck, and he is sent away, and his hand should not be moved for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And it is appropriate to put food on the wound lightly until the limb is restored; because it is more quickly healed in that way.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then a larger one should be put on after seven days or five, and he should be exercised with motion.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If it then becomes firm and does not soften, then he is already healed.Et si non, quod plerumque fit, debet aliter curari: nam in quibusdam placet, ut deinde ponantur super eam crepidae et straggulos cum oleo.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If, however, the joint becomes dislocated many times, because of the moisture that comes to it, or for some other reason: then a cautery with three holes should be administered on it, according to what was prescribed in the chapter on cauteries.Et postea debet ponere super eam emplastrum, quod praemissum est.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If this happens and the ligament is dissolved after seven days and the joint does not heal and the poultice is removed several times and it does not harden, and if it falls off and cannot be elevated upward: then know that the nerves which are near the head of the humerus have been cut, or stretched, or softened. And know that the joint will never heal in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	As for a dislocation which occurs towards the chest and breast or back, its reduction is achieved with pushing and extension by hand: until it goes back into place, and the remaining tightness is relieved and treated, until it heals.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If after healing there is heaviness in the limb and slowness of movement, then the patient should use a bath often, until that heaviness is eased and it returns to its former nature.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	¶ On curing a dislocated elbow.Capiatur ergo brachi dislocationis curanda, et ponatur super lathum, donec possit eleuare, et trahatur in primam positionem: postea utatur balneo tepidario multotiens, et administrete ei unguentum camphoratum, et linantur membra cum linteis, et imponantur super eum cataplasmata calida.
Caput XXVIII.	Take therefore a dislocated arm and place it on a board, until it can be elevated and drawn back into its first position; afterwards use a lukewarm bath often, and apply camphor ointment to it, and let the limbs be bound with linen cloths, and hot poultices be laid upon it.Chapter 28.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	Know that a dislocated elbow is dislocated and returns with difficulty, and it is dislocated to all parts, especially the front or back.Et notetur in dislocatione Cubiti, quod si fiat cum magna difficultate dislocatio eius ad posteriorem, et postea redit cum magna difficultate: tunc scias, quod nerui humerales sunt mollificati per dislocationem, et non possunt extendi.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation is not concealed from you; for it falls under sight and touch, and is displaced according to whatever shape it may be.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you join the dislocated elbow with the sound one, it is made clear to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	For the joint is sunken in, and cannot double the arm, nor touch its shoulder.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And it is necessary, that you should hasten and reduce the dislocation at once, before the warm pustule happens to it.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if the hot pustule happens to it, its reduction is difficult; and perhaps it is not healed at all, especially when it is behind.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	For it is worse in every way than any other dislocation, and the pain of it more violent; and death frequently ensues.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And its restoration when it is possible to reduce it, is, that the hand be extended with both hands: and the arm be expanded, and the physician's hands are above the elbow and under it, and he push the joint with the tips of his thumbs simultaneously, or with the root of his palms, until it return to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or else if the dislocation is before: then he returns it by doubling his hand with his hand, until he strikes with the root of his palm against the dislocated elbow.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	If the dislocation does not yield to reduction, then administer a very strong and violent extension; and it is, that two ministers hold the arm stretched out: and also that two ministers hold him, so that he does not move away from the extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then let the arm be turned about after a fold of cloth doubled long, or a broad band is wrapped over his hand.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when the physician touches the joint with his hand, he anoints it with oil: that it may be one of those things which help by lubricity and facility.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then let him push at the joint with a violent push, until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after its reduction it is necessary that a plaster be laid over it, in which there is astringency, and drying with white lead; and let it be bound with a decent bandage.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And let the arm of the sick person be suspended from his neck; and leave for several days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then it is healed.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If then the joint is made firm in its place, then loose the ligament from it, and leave it alone.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see that the joint is not well tightened, then repeat the ointment and the bandage, and leave it alone for several days until it is tightened.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then loose it.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	But if after the reduction of the joint, heaviness occurs and the condition is in movement: then administer a moistening in a bath, and a slight friction, and compression, until it is soothed, or place over the joint fat of lamb, that is, fat of ram.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then let it be bound, and leave it alone for a day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then take it off, and introduce the person into a bath.Et si non possit intraveri in balneum, illum in lecho subtegatur, et super eum humectationes fiant, et fricationes subtiles, et compressiones.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	And if he cannot go into a bath, let him be covered in bed, and moistening and mild friction, and compression, be done over him.When therefore he sweats, then rub the joint with moderate friction.Et quum per fricationem temperata sudat, tunc frica iuncturam, et solue eam, et ligaturem.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then repeat over it a soothed salve one, and a second, and a third time with entry into the bath until it is soothed.Et si non possit intraveri in balneum, illum in lecho subtegatur, et super eum fiant humectationes subtiles cum fricationibus temperatis, et compressionibus, donec leniatur, id est, donec sudet, et postea frica iuncturam.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if you wish, place on top of it excrement of a cow, moistened and warmed with butter, and press it onto the wound.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do this several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	For it softens it and restores it to its natural state.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	¶ On the treatment of a dislocation from the Al-Mahassen.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.De dislocatione humerı̈ in articulum antecubiti.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The joint which connects the arm and the hand is often dislocated.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And the reduction of this dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	On the contrary to other joints.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	However it is necessary that the reduction of this dislocation be quick in the hour when it was dislocated before a callus or a cold aposteme forms.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of this dislocation is such that you should place the patient's hand on a table and an assistant extend his hand, and the surgeon put his palm over the protuberance of the joint and push it until it returns to its proper position.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	However it is important to consider if the palm has already retreated toward the hand's wrist: then let the patient place his hand's back on a table at its extension and reduction; and if the dislocation is towards the back of the hand, then let the hand be positioned face down on the table, that is, let the interior part of his hand be placed upon the table so as to fall under the surgeon's palm which is over the protuberance of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	So if it goes back immediately, that is good; and if not, then bind it with a sedative plaster; and leave it, nor do this again.Et si redit et recidit iterum, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro uigili: et si recidit iterum, post unam diem et tertio die post dislocationem, tunc scies, quod non reducetur nisi cum magno periculum.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	And if it goes back and comes out again, then bind it with a strong plaster; and if it comes out again after one day and the third day after dislocation, then you will know that it can' be reduced without great danger.For if it does not tolerate and you cannot return to its reduction after one day has passed, the joint will remain bent as before; and this does no harm to the patient, except that his hand is relaxed and he cannot hold anything firmly: then you will know that the nerves are severed, or worn away.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	There is no remedy for it, therefore, except to bind it close to its socket with a ligature.Et si recidit iterum, tunc ponas eam super tabulam secundum prius positionem, et impellat medicus eminentiaram iuncturae cum manu sua donec redeat ad locum suum: et si non possis facere, neque redierit cum emplastro uigili aut sedante, tunc ponas eam super focum calidum, et facias eam ardere usque ad primam cutem, donec sentiat dolor.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps that does not bring anything about.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	And when he does not return to health, then place over him the plaster which we have described.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then let him be bound up and let go for five days; after that let him bathe and be let go, and exercise the hand.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	If however his movement is hindered and something of heaviness occurs in it; then make it easy with warm water and with friction several times, until it becomes easy.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	¶ Of the cure for dislocation of the fingers.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When a finger is dislocated to any part of the hand, or a finger to the back of the palm, or its hollow; then stretch out your finger and push against it with your thumbs until it returns to its place.Antidota contra omnem fracturam osorium.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the finger and suspend it turned towards the part to which it is dislocated, and leave it for two days.Si autem dislocationis non sit in extremitate Digiti, sed intra: tunc fac plaga in medio inter phalangas.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend him and extend him until he is straight on that day itself.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When night has therefore come, bind him according to the same account; and do not cease to loosen him during the day; and exercise him with motion; and bind him in the night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Do this for several days until he is tightened.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And likewise do with him if it be displaced to the belly-side; and bind him to the same side, and do with him your first operation until he be healed.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And likewise do with him when it is displaced to other parts.Et scito quod si fuit dislocatio magna, non debes extendi eum per gradus: sed debes extendi eum per gradus contrarios.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	¶ Of the cure of a dislocation of the vertebrae of the back.Nunc sequitur dislocationis dorsi cura, que est difficile et praecipua inter omnes: et sic debes procedere.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.De locatione dorsi per gradus contrarios.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When anyone's spine is broken or there is complete dislocation of the neck or many vertebrae are displaced from their places, then there is no cure for him because death is swift to come upon him.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	The sign of this is that the patient goes into convulsions without wanting to and cannot keep still; and often some members of his body are relaxed or both his legs or both his arms or one of them; or a single vertebra is displaced from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	For often there is removal to four parts, namely:
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	That which is displaced backwards is called Hunchback.Quod vero remouetur ad anteriora, nomini Croup.
