Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	The treatment for this is, to consider then, if the hunchback happens from childhood: then there is no cure for it, nor indeed any healing at all.Sed si uenerit de maiestate, tunc datur curatio.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	As for those injuries which happen by chance or as a result of a blow or similar occurrence, the ancient authorities have already spoken at length about their cure in their detailed discussions.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Most of these do not heal successfully.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I have already mentioned that, which hardly needs an excuse on my part because of the great amount it owes to its proximity to me and to my interpretation of it; and also because I described it in different terms from those used by others who have described it before, and because I gave a description of the instrument from a different viewpoint.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I say then that there is no cure for a bump which occurs on the front part.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And likewise for one which occurs on both sides.Quamvis namque excisionem facias illum cum ingenio qui consueuit, non tamen redit cum proficuo.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And it is not cured by them, except that which happens on the back properly speaking, with what I am about to say; and it is when the invalid is made to lie on his face over an even surface close to a wall, and a wet mattress spread out under him so that his breast does not get hurt.Hic enim sedet sub eo per duo vel tres dies donec consuitur: et postea faciatur super eum linteus humidus prope parietem in modum torsi, et faciat urinas super eum quae erunt salubres ei.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Here he remains for two or three days until the wound heals; and then a wet towel is placed over him near the wall, in the shape of a roll, and urine is poured on him which will be beneficial to him.Then a straight piece of wood is fixed in the floor, at the end of the bed, about his head; and another piece of wood about his feet at the other end of the bed; and an attendant holds the wood, which is not firmly fixed in the floor.Et trahatur illum ad se, et abjicitur lignum de fouea cum ingenio cuiuslibet: et faciatur super eum linteus humidus, ut non laedatur pectus eius.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And one assistant should hold another.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then wrap a bandage around the patient's head, and under his armpits a gentle, yet firm bandage; and extend the end of the bandage to the post at the head of the bed, and tie it there.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then tighten another bandage over his hips, and over his knees, and by his ankles.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then gather all the bandages and tie them to another post at the foot of the bed.Et sic fac ut mensura ligaminum sit super caput eius, et supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et supra cauillas eius.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then each assistant must stretch the bandages to one side of the post, and not move either post from where it is fixed; yet they should not be tightened as we have said before.Et sic faciamus, et mensurabimus.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And thus it shall be done and measured.And the doctor must place his palms firmly over the vertebrae, until he returns; or he must place a board over her.Et faciat sic, donec confirmetur.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he must attach his feet to the board, until he returns.Et faciat sic, donec confirmetur.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	If however, he does not return after this treatment, then take a board whose length is about three armspans.Et ponat eam inter spondiles.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And place it between the vertebrae.And let the end of the board find a place in the wall of which we spoke before, on the side of the patient.Et annecte extremitatem tabulae ad parietem per ligaturas.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then put the medium of the table over the vertebrae.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And let the doctor put his feet on the other end.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And it is tied well until the vertebrae are tightened and return to their place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then if you want to operate with a hand turn as it is wrapped around your hand and it is as if you fix the ground at the head of the patient two feet in the last of the pod two woods whose length is brachii one and at his head in the last two feet of the pod.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And let the length between all wood palm one be and now it is made in all place hole in which runs turn and wood is firmly all much earth that it is not moved at all.Et si non possit per tornum fieri, sedatur infirmus ad pedes in extremitate alteri: et ponatur sub capite eius ligna duo: et super eadem ponatur medium tabulae, et super eam medicus, qui operatur: et ad caput eius apud postremum podium.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And if it can not be done by turn but the patient is seated at feet in other end and put under his head two woods and above them medium of table and above it doctor who operates and to his head in last podium and put round wood and it is turn in which rolled ligament in two holes of two woods.Et si non possit per tornum fieri, sedatur infirmus ad pedes in extremitate alteri: et ponatur sub capite eius ligna duo: et super eadem ponatur medium tabulae, et super eam medicus, qui operatur: et ad caput eius apud postremum podium.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And if it can not be done by turn but the patient is seated at feet in other end and put under his head two woods and above them medium of table and above it doctor who operates and to his head in last podium a nd in its end is hole in which wood is firmed whose length palm with that which is rolled and in two other woods likewise.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then tie the ligaments which you tied in breast of patient around turn which is at his head and the ligaments which you tied in his legs in turn which is at his feet.Et sic faciendum est, donec ligaturas consint: et postea ligaturae solvantur: et confrimetur spondilis locum suum per omnia.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then a helper stands beside each tourniquet, who twists his hand with a linen cloth around the tourniquet, as we said; and the doctor equalizes the pulley according to what has been said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the tourniquet that follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then after the pulley returns and is leveled, then one must put on a dried plaster with white of egg.
Deinde stuppam.	Then bandage it.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Then put above the plaster a star out of a table, whose width is three fingers, or about them.Et sic facies omnes dies, donec curent lavescunturque cruores, quos vides.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length the quantity which receives the place of the Gibbosity, and over the part of the pulley that is healthy. And you do this every day until the open sores are closed and the blood flow is stopped.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then it is bound with a bandage as we said.Postea, ubi cadaverem habuerit septem dies, et cruor stet quietum et stabilis, tunc oportet, ut remoueret eam medicus, qui scit locum et omnia, quae postea diximus.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And let the sick person be fed subtle nourishment until he is healed.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	And if something outstanding remains in the place at the end of the healing: then it is necessary that medicines which soften and soothe be administered with the administration of the tablet which we have narrated about a long time ago.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And now the lead plate is administered.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And sometimes a突出occurs at last in the spine: and it is thought to be a displacement, and that bone which now protrudes.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore, this medicine should not be presumed with him; perhaps indeed it will bring about death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	¶ On the cure of a displaced Ankle.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	You should know that the joints of the ankle and the shoulder do not occur unless there is a displacement; nor do they occur to them what happens to other joints from a small removal and depression.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And indeed the joint of the ankle is displaced according to four parts.Quarta, et prima parte: quando superius tali modo est dislocatum, ut posuerit in inferius, quasi quasi supplicium: nam eminente os superius supra os inferius dislocatur quasi in concauitate.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	The fourth and first part: when the upper is displaced such that it is placed on the lower, almost like a punishment; for the protruding upper bone above the lower bone is displaced, as if in a depression.This is because it is displaced forward and backward.Secunda parte: quando dislocatur superius tali modo, ut posuerit parum supra inferius: sed non tantum, ut concauitas sit in os superius.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	The second part: when the upper is displaced such that it lies a little above the lower, but not so much that there is a depression in the upper bone.And indeed it is mostly displaced inward; and it is slightly displaced forward and backward.Tertia parte: quando dislocatur superius tali modo, ut posuerit infra inferius parum: et concauitas in os superius.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	The third part: when the upper is displaced such that it lies below the lower a little; and there is a depression in the upper bone.And the cure of its displacement inward is: because when you join the leg of an infirm person with a healthy person, it is longer; and its knee is protruding more than the healthy one, and the infirm cannot double his foot at the hip; and there is a place which follows the hip apostemated with an apostemate hot, because indeed the head of the hip has already arrived there.Et si dislocatio accidit tali modo: et superius taliter posuerit in inferius, quasi supplicium: est curatio eius, quod tu coniungis crura sancta sano cum infirmo, et facies os superius dislocatum intra inferius: sed non debet dislocare superius super inferius.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	And the sign of the person upon whom dislocation has occurred is in relation to the exterior parts, and the contrary of these accidents belong to it.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And the sign of him to whom dislocation occurs towards the front is that he stretches the sound leg according to its complement; but does not double it without pain in the knee; and if he attempts to walk, he cannot get over it towards the front; his urine is retained, and his groin swells up, and there is a bruise on his heel when he walks.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	And the sign of him to whom dislocation occurs towards the rear is that he does not stretch his knee, nor can he double it before doubling his groin; and his leg also is shorter than the other; and his groin is relaxed, and there is a protuberance on the head of the hip at the site of the ilium.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	Now the reduction of this dislocation consists in your then considering whether it is a recent dislocation, which has just occurred while he still had it.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you administer its reduction and it remains according to its arrangement; then there is no cure for it at all.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore it is not necessary that complete presumption be made for him.Et si dislocatio est recentior, quae non permanet post hoc ad instans cum administranda est reductione: sed est in ea curatio per medicasiones.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	But in him whose dislocation is recent and is of one of the four species, then hasten to loosen the joint, and extend it towards both the interior and exterior parts, and move it to the right and left; for perhaps it will return, and will not need any other treatment.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	But if it does not return in this way, then you must prepare a strong assistant and extend his leg from the lower part; or with your hands, or with a bandage which is bound over his leg above the knee: and another assistant must extend his hand over him so as to put his fingers under his toenails.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then he is to draw tight with a gentle bandage over the root of the hip, and hold the end of the other bandage.Et si non possunt reducere eam ad instans: sed quod faciunt est ineaue per medicasiones multum uoluntatis, et per medicamenta calida: et debent extendere super ligaturam desuper, et sub titillicis eius: et debet ministrus fortis inclinare crurem cum manibus suis ad exteriora, et alter ad interiora.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And let its extension be from the anterior part of the groin towards the furcula, or from the posterior to the part of the back.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And let their extension all be at once, until the invalid is raised up from off the earth with his body, and remain hanging.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	And this kind of extension is a common kind of four kinds.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If therefore the dislocation returns with it that which we have said, it is good; and if not, then it is necessary to each kind that which I say of the proper cure.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Indeed in the proper reduction when the dislocation is towards the bowels, it is necessary that the invalid be laid on his sound side.Et si ad exteriora dislocata est, resupinus debet intrare contra partem dislocationis.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then he should lay hold of the tendon which is over the root of the hip, in that which is between the head of the hip and the place which is under the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the tendon upwards from the side of the groin to the higher part of the body, towards the fork.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then another assistant should take hold of his strong arm and lessen the thick place of the weak hip, and extend it outwards with a violent extension.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	For now he has returned to his place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this kind is easier than other kinds of treatment by which this limb is reduced.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	But if he excuses himself to you and does not obey you at all in entering with this kind of treatment, then it is necessary that both feet of the infirm person should be bound together with a strong tendon, gently, over the two heels, and over the two knees; and let the length of each from its companion be four fingers: and let the infirm leg be extended more by two fingers' length.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then let the infirm person be suspended over the head of a wooden beam, which is in the house; and let its distance from the ground be two arms' length.Deinde ponatur sub pedibus eius ligno: et super eum ligentur lintei ad fastidiem, quod faciat ut non cadat super terram.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then let a board be placed under his feet; and over him let linen bandages be bound to fasten, so that he does not fall on the ground. Then order a strong youth to guard the head of the hip; and let another youth be suspended with the infirm person; and let one youth push another who is guarding the hip with strength, for the joint returns to its place with speed.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	However, in its own return when there is a dislocation outwards, it is necessary that the infirm person should lie on an elevation, according as we have narrated in the one having a hunchback.Et quando est dislocatio ad interiora, oportet, ut iaceat super terram.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And a bandage should be tied over his thigh, his weak one, and over his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then two pieces of wood are to be placed, one by the feet of the patient and the other at the head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then another piece of wood is to be placed in the middle of the stretcher, firmly fixed, over which are spread wet sheets so that the patient is not hurt; and the piece of wood must be between his thighs so that he is not pulled down toward the lower part of the stretcher when he is raised.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then all the attendants are to pull on their side, and the doctor with his own hand is to make the adjustment even.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If he resists returning, it will be good.Et si quid oboedierit in contrarium, et non obeuat seque inueterat, medicus manibus suis retineat eum in statione ad qua elapsus est, et ministeres manibus suos relaxent: et sic iterum extendant, donec fit aeternum.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place over it a board and press it as we said regarding the hump equally.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	However, the sick person must lie on his healthy side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is towards the front, then the sick person's leg must be quickly extended; and it is according to this same account on top of the platform; and the doctor should place the palm of his right hand over the hip of the sick person.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he pulls it with his other hand, and with that pull he places the extended sick person towards the lower part of the knee.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	And if the dislocation is towards the back: then the sick person must not be extended towards the lower part and be raised above the ground; rather he must be placed over a hard object, as it must also be done when his hip is dislocated outwards, according to what we said about his lying on both hips; and it is on its side, and with the ligaments extended: according to what we said recently.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it is necessary that a compress with a board be also applied over the place from which the joint will come out, when the reduction is completed as it should be.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of its return will not be hidden from you; and it is that you extend the two legs of the sick person; and when you see them equal, and the sick person pulls his leg, and extends it without excuse: then know that the limb has returned as it should; then join the two hips, and place a poultice, and press with an ungreased cloth, that is, a wheel: so that the hip does not move to any part; and the sick person adheres to rest for three days, or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then loosen the bandage and the poultice, and compare the leg with the other; then if you see them equal in status, know that the dislocation is now healed: therefore let the sick person go about his business.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see some softening; then return and poultice it again, and press it according to your first pressing; and leave it also for three days.Et si non redit, ita facias cum eo tres dies, donec uides molle factum: et quando uides illud uestigem factum, scias, quod dislocatio firmata est completum.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then loosen it and make him walk on both feet for a few days until he is fully healed.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	§ On dislocation of the knee.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.De dislocatione genu.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The knee joint may be dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	It is dislocated outwards, inwards and downwards, that is to say backwards.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	And it is not dislocated forwards.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	And the sign of its dislocation is this: you must order the sick person to apply his shin to his hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	If, however, it does not adhere to the hip then you should know that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	And the restoration of all its modes of dislocation is this: you must make the sick person sit straight, so that he can now stretch his shin over it, and adhere to your back to his face; and place his foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then make the knee adhere with your palms, and straighten them between your fingers over its knee.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply with your palm the two sides of its knee firmly.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another assistant should stretch his foot until the knee returns to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	And the sign of its restoration is that the shin adheres to the hip easily, not with effort.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then bandage it and make the shin adhere to the hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind them together for three days or four.
Deinde solue ea.	Then loosen them.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And let the sick person not use walking for several days until he is healed.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	If, however, its reduction refuses you then administer a strong extension with ligatures, of which the precedent narrative was mentioned in the cure of an ankle, until it returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	¶ On the cure of a dislocated heel.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	The heel is sometimes removed with a small removal and sometimes dislocated according to its complement.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	And its dislocation is made either inwards or outwards.Et quilibet modum tibi indicabit signum.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	And the sign of its displacement is that you see the calcaneus swollen, going towards the side to which it is displaced.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	The treatment of its removal, however, is easy extension: and it is that the foot be easily stretched with the hands, and made even, until it returns to normal.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	However, when it is cured and dislocated according to the complement, you must cause the invalid to sit upright: and a very strong assistant must hold him from behind by his shoulder, in front of him.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then you hold with your right hand the upper part of his foot, and with your left hand under the lower part of the foot in place of the ball.Et inclinato pedi valde ad partem dislocationis ad qua dislocatur: et remittendo manibus ad modum ligaturae redderis in locum suum.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then draw the foot towards you with your right hand, and while you release it gently like a ligature, return it to its place. Then pull the foot toward you with your right hand.Et sic iterum remittendo: et trahendis pedem ad te per modum ligaturae iterum redderis in locum suum.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	And so again by releasing and pulling the foot towards you by means of a ligature, return it to its place. Then with two fingers of your left hand.Et remittendo per modum ligaturae: et trahendis pedem ad te redderis in locum suum.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	And releasing by means of a ligature and pulling the foot towards you, return it to its place. Then extend with your left hand and push the breast of the foot with your right hand turned towards the thigh without effort.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do that twice as we have described.Et sic remittere pedem in locum suum: et deinde superueniant viri fortes eam partem dislocationis per modum ligaturae, donec redierit.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then return the foot to its place and then strong men should support that part of the dislocation by means of a ligature until it returns to normal. Then push the breast of the foot against the thigh for a third time, while you pull the ball.Et remittendo: et trahendis pedem ad te per modum ligaturae redderis in locum suum.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	And releasing and pulling the foot towards you by means of a ligature, return it to its place. If it returns in one turn or two turns according to this manner, and you see the foot even, then it is good; but if not, then repeat the operation on him again, for he will return.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	But if it is prohibited for you to return it according to what we have described, then let the invalid lie on his back on the ground and fix a small peg firmly in the ground so that it falls between his thighs; and you have already wrapped a cloth over him so as not to hurt the invalid.Et tene cum manibus tuo superiorem pedis dislocati: et impelle paxillum per interius ad partem dislocationis, donec uides dislocationem remisiuam: et si non, itera operationem.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then let the assistant take hold of the thigh; then have the other assistant stretch out a leg with his hand or with a bandage bound around the ankle.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then let all the assistants stretch out opposite to the stretch of their companion; and have a pillow placed between the two thighs of the patient, so that his body is not drawn towards the lower part by the stretching.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then the surgeon equalizes the dislocation with his hands; and let the other assistant hold the sound leg downward.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For the dislocation returns with speed.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	When therefore the dislocation returns and is declared to you to be restored to health; then put on the plaster and poultice, and bind it up firmly with bandages, and tie the foot to the thigh with a bandage.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And it is necessary that you be careful or fearful of the nerves which are above the posterior heel-bone, so that the bandage does not press upon them and injure them.Et postea lega crura et pedes cum fascibus firmiter.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then leave it for two days, or three.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If the ligament softens, then tie it up; then loosen it on the third or fourth day; and prevent the patient from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	But if he tries to walk before that time, there is no certainty but that the dislocation will be dissolved and corrupted, and will not receive healing afterwards.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If a hot ulcer should arise on it: then you must administer to its relief that which was mentioned before in the narrative in another place as regards treatment, and an embrocation, until it is relieved.Quod si accidat ei contusio, oportet ut embrocatio sit in parte, et frictiones, donec sedant.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	¶ Of the dislocation of the toes, and its treatment.Si digitus pedis dislocatur: fac embrocationem cum vino tepidario et uino rubrio, et frictiones in locis conuersis pedis: et oportet ut stet quiete quadraginta dies.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.De dislocatione maninis, et cura.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	Of the dislocation of the fingers and its treatment.It must be placed in alignment with a slight extension without pain; and that indeed is not difficult, rather it is easy.Si autem non possit, ut adueneretur sese quod necesse sit cum labore: oportet ut trahat eam ad flexum extremum, et frictione sedantur digitus pedis cum vino tepidario et uino rubrio.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	But if it cannot be brought into alignment without pain: then it must be pulled towards the extreme flexion, and the fingers of the foot must be rubbed until they are sedated with tepid wine and red wine.If however the dislocation is in some of the joints of the back of the foot: then the invalid must sit with his foot on a level with the ground, or on a board; and he must stand as if walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then you must stand, and place your foot over that which protrudes from those joints.Fac embrocationes in pedibus cum oleo et uino tepidario: ut sedant dolores.Deinde dimitte ipsum ad curam quadraginta dies, donec remoueatur dislocatio, et quiescat illud quod contusio erat super eum.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then press it down with your foot with force, until it returns to its place; and you will see it already made even, and no protuberance will appear at the site.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then place under his foot a board which will hold his whole foot, to which there are two heads.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then tighten it with a decent ligature for three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then loosen it, and let him rest from walking many days until he is bound and secured from the reduction.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	Of the species of dislocations with a wound or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something happens to it, and you try to cure it, and its restoration, often death ensues; and because of this he should not presume to superintend its cure unless he is wise in the art of long use, merciful, pious, slow to anger, not bold, nor presumptuous: and that he make use in the application of medicines which alone soothe apostemata hot only. And let the feeble go by divine judgement.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you see or hope for salvation from destruction with mildness of sickness, and in which something of hope appears.De dislocationibus capite percutito.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Endeavor therefore at its reduction immediately in the beginning of the thing, before an apostema hot happens.De dislocatione capitis mortuis cadente.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If then the limb returns according to our wish, administer the regime that calms the abscess; and treat the wound with what suits it from the drying ointments.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If it is a dislocation with fracture and there are separated fragments of bone, then try their removal and do in that what we said before in simple diseases at the places of these.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And beware according to your strength and guard yourself against falling into the way of fear; according to what my prophecy went before you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For it is better for you with your creator and more permanent for your glory; and more safe for your body among them during your time.
